title: 110_hr92
content: The Act titled "Veterans Timely Access to Health Care Act" establishes standards for access to care. The Act "Veterans Timely Access to Health Care Act" amends Section 1703 of title 38, United States Code, to establish a 30-day standard for access to primary care for veterans seeking care from the Department. The Secretary is required to set a standard for waiting times at Department health-care facilities and review their performance periodically. The Act "Veterans Timely Access to Health Care Act" establishes a 30-day standard for access to primary care for veterans. The Secretary must report annually on the Department's performance in meeting this standard. If the standard is not met, the Secretary can provide care in non-Department facilities, with payment limitations. The Act "Veterans Timely Access to Health Care Act" sets a 30-day standard for veterans' access to primary care. If the standard is not met at a Department facility, veterans can receive care at non-Department facilities with payment limitations. Non-Department facilities cannot bill veterans for any difference between their charges and the amount paid by the Secretary. Veterans enrolled or seeking care at a Department facility with a compliance rate of 90% or more for access to care standards are exempt from this provision. The Secretary determines compliance rates for each Department geographic service area. The Secretary is required to submit quarterly reports to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding waiting times for veterans seeking appointments with Department health-care providers. The report must include the total number of veterans waiting in different categories based on waiting times, ranging from under 30 days to over 4 months. The Secretary must submit quarterly reports to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs detailing waiting times for veterans seeking care. The report should categorize veterans based on different waiting times, including those waiting under 30 days, between 30 days and 6 months, over 6 months but within 9 months, over 9 months but within a year, and any remaining veterans who cannot be scheduled. The report should also distinguish between waiting times for primary care and specialty care, as well as for newly enrolled veterans versus those enrolled before October 1, 2001. Additionally, the report should include the number of veterans who have enrolled but have not sought care at a Department health care facility. The final report for this requirement should cover the quarter ending on December 31, 2010. The effective date for subsection (e) of section 1703 of title 38, United States Code, added by the Act, is the first day of the first month beginning more than six months after the enactment. The first report under that subsection is due for the quarter ending on December 31 of the first calendar year after the enactment.
